title: (x) Looking for good old-school typewriter font - various {gang}
content:
I’m looking for a/some good oldschool-typewriter-stylisch font(s).  
Something a little less tight or clean than a Courier.

I’m looking for a font wich contains elements like a closed “e” and stuff like that.

Can anyone help me out? I’d appreciate it very much!

 [‹ Moet & Chandon Champagne font](http://web.archive.org/web/20081006113153/http:/typophile.com/node/2222 "Go to previous forum topic") [(x) Niagara Falls Font - Party, Fashion Compressed {Mike F, Mark S} ›](http://web.archive.org/web/20081006113153/http:/typophile.com/node/15670 "Go to next forum topic")
author: Maas

comments.content:
Lineto has got good typewriter fonts, even Normetica is a cool “courier” flavoured font, but maybe too modern for you.

check them out: [Lineto](http://web.archive.org/web/20081006113153/http:/www.lineto.com/)
Maas go to any of the commercial type vendors, like sponsor, FontFont and in the search area type in typewriter. You will get a lot of choices.
How about [Schmutz Clogged](http://web.archive.org/web/20081006113153/http:/www.identifont.com/show?8SQ), if I may be so bold as to recommend one of my own?

Nothing beats FF Trixie, it has different versions for different amount of dirt. It was the first and still is the most original, by Erik van Blokland:

[http://www.fontfont.com/shop/](http://web.archive.org/web/20081006113153/http:/www.fontfont.com/shop/ "http://www.fontfont.com/shop/")
Why is it we often overlook the obvious choice? :^)
